2661@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

2662def csv2rec(fname, comments='#', skiprows=0, checkrows=0, delimiter=',', 

2663 converterd=None, names=None, missing='', missingd=None, 

2664 use_mrecords=False, dayfirst=False, yearfirst=False): 

2665 """ 

2666 Load data from comma/space/tab delimited file in *fname* into a 

2667 numpy record array and return the record array. 

2668 

2669 If *names* is *None*, a header row is required to automatically 

2670 assign the recarray names. The headers will be lower cased, 

2671 spaces will be converted to underscores, and illegal attribute 

2672 name characters removed. If *names* is not *None*, it is a 

2673 sequence of names to use for the column names. In this case, it 

2674 is assumed there is no header row. 

2675 

2676 

2677 - *fname*: can be a filename or a file handle. Support for gzipped 

2678 files is automatic, if the filename ends in '.gz' 

2679 

2680 - *comments*: the character used to indicate the start of a comment 

2681 in the file, or *None* to switch off the removal of comments 

2682 

2683 - *skiprows*: is the number of rows from the top to skip 

2684 

2685 - *checkrows*: is the number of rows to check to validate the column 

2686 data type. When set to zero all rows are validated. 

2687 

2688 - *converterd*: if not *None*, is a dictionary mapping column number or 

2689 munged column name to a converter function. 

2690 

2691 - *names*: if not None, is a list of header names. In this case, no 

2692 header will be read from the file 

2693 

2694 - *missingd* is a dictionary mapping munged column names to field values 

2695 which signify that the field does not contain actual data and should 

2696 be masked, e.g., '0000-00-00' or 'unused' 

2697 

2698 - *missing*: a string whose value signals a missing field regardless of 

2699 the column it appears in 

2700 

2701 - *use_mrecords*: if True, return an mrecords.fromrecords record array if 

2702 any of the data are missing 

2703 

2704 - *dayfirst*: default is False so that MM-DD-YY has precedence over 

2705 DD-MM-YY. See 

2706 http://labix.org/python-dateutil#head-b95ce2094d189a89f80f5ae52a05b4ab7b41af47 

2707 for further information. 

2708 

2709 - *yearfirst*: default is False so that MM-DD-YY has precedence over 

2710 YY-MM-DD. See 

2711 http://labix.org/python-dateutil#head-b95ce2094d189a89f80f5ae52a05b4ab7b41af47 

2712 for further information. 

2713 

2714 If no rows are found, *None* is returned 

2715 """ 

2716 

2717 if converterd is None: 

2718 converterd = dict() 

2719 

2720 if missingd is None: 

2721 missingd = {} 

2722 

2723 import dateutil.parser 

2724 import datetime 

2725 

2726 fh = cbook.to_filehandle(fname) 

2727 

2728 delimiter = str(delimiter) 

2729 

2730 class FH: 

2731 """ 

2732 For space-delimited files, we want different behavior than 

2733 comma or tab. Generally, we want multiple spaces to be 

2734 treated as a single separator, whereas with comma and tab we 

2735 want multiple commas to return multiple (empty) fields. The 

2736 join/strip trick below effects this. 

2737 """ 

2738 def __init__(self, fh): 

2739 self.fh = fh 

2740 

2741 def close(self): 

2742 self.fh.close() 

2743 

2744 def seek(self, arg): 

2745 self.fh.seek(arg) 

2746 

2747 def fix(self, s): 

2748 return ' '.join(s.split()) 

2749 

2750 def __next__(self): 

2751 return self.fix(next(self.fh)) 

2752 

2753 def __iter__(self): 

2754 for line in self.fh: 

2755 yield self.fix(line) 

2756 

2757 if delimiter == ' ': 

2758 fh = FH(fh) 

2759 

2760 reader = csv.reader(fh, delimiter=delimiter) 

2761 

2762 def process_skiprows(reader): 

2763 if skiprows: 

2764 for i, row in enumerate(reader): 

2765 if i >= (skiprows-1): 

2766 break 

2767 

2768 return fh, reader 

2769 

2770 process_skiprows(reader) 

2771 

2772 def ismissing(name, val): 

2773 "Should the value val in column name be masked?" 

2774 return val == missing or val == missingd.get(name) or val == '' 

2775 

2776 def with_default_value(func, default): 

2777 def newfunc(name, val): 

2778 if ismissing(name, val): 

2779 return default 

2780 else: 

2781 return func(val) 

2782 return newfunc 

2783 

2784 def mybool(x): 

2785 if x == 'True': 

2786 return True 

2787 elif x == 'False': 

2788 return False 

2789 else: 

2790 raise ValueError('invalid bool') 

2791 

2792 dateparser = dateutil.parser.parse 

2793 

2794 def mydateparser(x): 

2795 # try and return a datetime object 

2796 d = dateparser(x, dayfirst=dayfirst, yearfirst=yearfirst) 

2797 return d 

2798 

2799 mydateparser = with_default_value(mydateparser, datetime.datetime(1, 1, 1)) 

2800 

2801 myfloat = with_default_value(float, np.nan) 

2802 myint = with_default_value(int, -1) 

2803 mystr = with_default_value(str, '') 

2804 mybool = with_default_value(mybool, None) 

2805 

2806 def mydate(x): 

2807 # try and return a date object 

2808 d = dateparser(x, dayfirst=dayfirst, yearfirst=yearfirst) 

2809 

2810 if d.hour > 0 or d.minute > 0 or d.second > 0: 

2811 raise ValueError('not a date') 

2812 return d.date() 

2813 mydate = with_default_value(mydate, datetime.date(1, 1, 1)) 

2814 

2815 def get_func(name, item, func): 

2816 # promote functions in this order 

2817 funcs = [mybool, myint, myfloat, mydate, mydateparser, mystr] 

2818 for func in funcs[funcs.index(func):]: 

2819 try: 

2820 func(name, item) 

2821 except Exception: 

2822 continue 

2823 return func 

2824 raise ValueError('Could not find a working conversion function') 

2825 

2826 # map column names that clash with builtins -- TODO - extend this list 

2827 itemd = { 

2828 'return': 'return_', 

2829 'file': 'file_', 

2830 'print': 'print_', 

2831 } 

2832 

2833 def get_converters(reader, comments): 

2834 

2835 converters = None 

2836 i = 0 

2837 for row in reader: 

2838 if (len(row) and comments is not None and 

2839 row[0].startswith(comments)): 

2840 continue 

2841 if i == 0: 

2842 converters = [mybool]*len(row) 

2843 if checkrows and i > checkrows: 

2844 break 

2845 i += 1 

2846 

2847 for j, (name, item) in enumerate(zip(names, row)): 

2848 func = converterd.get(j) 

2849 if func is None: 

2850 func = converterd.get(name) 

2851 if func is None: 

2852 func = converters[j] 

2853 if len(item.strip()): 

2854 func = get_func(name, item, func) 

2855 else: 

2856 # how should we handle custom converters and defaults? 

2857 func = with_default_value(func, None) 

2858 converters[j] = func 

2859 return converters 

2860 

2861 # Get header and remove invalid characters 

2862 needheader = names is None 

2863 

2864 if needheader: 

2865 for row in reader: 

2866 if (len(row) and comments is not None and 

2867 row[0].startswith(comments)): 

2868 continue 

2869 headers = row 

2870 break 

2871 

2872 # remove these chars 

2873 delete = set(r"""~!@#$%^&*()-=+~\|}[]{';: /?.>,<""") 

2874 delete.add('"') 

2875 

2876 names = [] 

2877 seen = dict() 

2878 for i, item in enumerate(headers): 

2879 item = item.strip().lower().replace(' ', '_') 

2880 item = ''.join([c for c in item if c not in delete]) 

2881 if not len(item): 

2882 item = 'column%d' % i 

2883 

2884 item = itemd.get(item, item) 

2885 cnt = seen.get(item, 0) 

2886 if cnt > 0: 

2887 names.append(item + '_%d' % cnt) 

2888 else: 

2889 names.append(item) 

2890 seen[item] = cnt+1 

2891 

2892 else: 

2893 if isinstance(names, str): 

2894 names = [n.strip() for n in names.split(',')] 

2895 

2896 # get the converter functions by inspecting checkrows 

2897 converters = get_converters(reader, comments) 

2898 if converters is None: 

2899 raise ValueError('Could not find any valid data in CSV file') 

2900 

2901 # reset the reader and start over 

2902 fh.seek(0) 

2903 reader = csv.reader(fh, delimiter=delimiter) 

2904 process_skiprows(reader) 

2905 

2906 if needheader: 

2907 while True: 

2908 # skip past any comments and consume one line of column header 

2909 row = next(reader) 

2910 if (len(row) and comments is not None and 

2911 row[0].startswith(comments)): 

2912 continue 

2913 break 

2914 

2915 # iterate over the remaining rows and convert the data to date 

2916 # objects, ints, or floats as appropriate 

2917 rows = [] 

2918 rowmasks = [] 

2919 for i, row in enumerate(reader): 

2920 if not len(row): 

2921 continue 

2922 if comments is not None and row[0].startswith(comments): 

2923 continue 

2924 # Ensure that the row returned always has the same nr of elements 

2925 row.extend([''] * (len(converters) - len(row))) 

2926 rows.append([func(name, val) 

2927 for func, name, val in zip(converters, names, row)]) 

2928 rowmasks.append([ismissing(name, val) 

2929 for name, val in zip(names, row)]) 

2930 fh.close() 

2931 

2932 if not len(rows): 

2933 return None 

2934 

2935 if use_mrecords and np.any(rowmasks): 

2936 r = np.ma.mrecords.fromrecords(rows, names=names, mask=rowmasks) 

2937 else: 

2938 r = np.rec.fromrecords(rows, names=names) 

2939 return r

2942# a series of classes for describing the format intentions of various rec views 

2943@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

2944class FormatObj(object): 

2945 def tostr(self, x): 

2946 return self.toval(x) 

2947 

2948 def toval(self, x): 

2949 return str(x) 

2950 

2951 def fromstr(self, s): 

2952 return s 

2953 

2954 def __hash__(self): 

2955 """ 

2956 override the hash function of any of the formatters, so that we don't 

2957 create duplicate excel format styles 

2958 """ 

2959 return hash(self.__class__) 

2960 

2961 

2962@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

2963class FormatString(FormatObj): 

2964 def tostr(self, x): 

2965 val = repr(x) 

2966 return val[1:-1] 

2967 

2968 

2969@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

2970class FormatFormatStr(FormatObj): 

2971 def __init__(self, fmt): 

2972 self.fmt = fmt 

2973 

2974 def tostr(self, x): 

2975 if x is None: 

2976 return 'None' 

2977 return self.fmt % self.toval(x) 

2978 

2979 

2980@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

2981class FormatFloat(FormatFormatStr): 

2982 def __init__(self, precision=4, scale=1.): 

2983 FormatFormatStr.__init__(self, '%%1.%df' % precision) 

2984 self.precision = precision 

2985 self.scale = scale 

2986 

2987 def __hash__(self): 

2988 return hash((self.__class__, self.precision, self.scale)) 

2989 

2990 def toval(self, x): 

2991 if x is not None: 

2992 x = x * self.scale 

2993 return x 

2994 

2995 def fromstr(self, s): 

2996 return float(s)/self.scale 

2997 

2998 

2999@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3000class FormatInt(FormatObj): 

3001 

3002 def tostr(self, x): 

3003 return '%d' % int(x) 

3004 

3005 def toval(self, x): 

3006 return int(x) 

3007 

3008 def fromstr(self, s): 

3009 return int(s) 

3010

3013class FormatBool(FormatObj):

3016 

3017 def fromstr(self, s): 

3018 return bool(s)

3067@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3068def get_formatd(r, formatd=None): 

3069 'build a formatd guaranteed to have a key for every dtype name' 

3070 defaultformatd = { 

3071 np.bool_: FormatBool(), 

3072 np.int16: FormatInt(), 

3073 np.int32: FormatInt(), 

3074 np.int64: FormatInt(), 

3075 np.float32: FormatFloat(), 

3076 np.float64: FormatFloat(), 

3077 np.object_: FormatObj(), 

3078 np.string_: FormatString()} 

3079 

3080 if formatd is None: 

3081 formatd = dict() 

3082 

3083 for i, name in enumerate(r.dtype.names): 

3084 dt = r.dtype[name] 

3085 format = formatd.get(name) 

3086 if format is None: 

3087 format = defaultformatd.get(dt.type, FormatObj()) 

3088 formatd[name] = format 

3089 return formatd

3101@cbook.deprecated("2.2", alternative='numpy.recarray.tofile') 

3102def rec2txt(r, header=None, padding=3, precision=3, fields=None): 

3103 """ 

3104 Returns a textual representation of a record array. 

3105 

3106 Parameters 

3107 ---------- 

3108 r: numpy recarray 

3109 

3110 header: list 

3111 column headers 

3112 

3113 padding: 

3114 space between each column 

3115 

3116 precision: number of decimal places to use for floats. 

3117 Set to an integer to apply to all floats. Set to a 

3118 list of integers to apply precision individually. 

3119 Precision for non-floats is simply ignored. 

3120 

3121 fields : list 

3122 If not None, a list of field names to print. fields 

3123 can be a list of strings like ['field1', 'field2'] or a single 

3124 comma separated string like 'field1,field2' 

3125 

3126 Examples 

3127 -------- 

3128 

3129 For ``precision=[0,2,3]``, the output is :: 

3130 

3131 ID Price Return 

3132 ABC 12.54 0.234 

3133 XYZ 6.32 -0.076 

3134 """ 

3135 

3136 if fields is not None: 

3137 r = rec_keep_fields(r, fields) 

3138 

3139 if cbook.is_numlike(precision): 

3140 precision = [precision]*len(r.dtype) 

3141 

3142 def get_type(item, atype=int): 

3143 tdict = {None: int, int: float, float: str} 

3144 try: 

3145 atype(str(item)) 

3146 except: 

3147 return get_type(item, tdict[atype]) 

3148 return atype 

3149 

3150 def get_justify(colname, column, precision): 

3151 ntype = column.dtype 

3152 

3153 if np.issubdtype(ntype, np.character): 

3154 fixed_width = int(ntype.str[2:]) 

3155 length = max(len(colname), fixed_width) 

3156 return 0, length+padding, "%s" # left justify 

3157 

3158 if np.issubdtype(ntype, np.integer): 

3159 length = max(len(colname), 

3160 np.max(list(map(len, list(map(str, column)))))) 

3161 return 1, length+padding, "%d" # right justify 

3162 

3163 if np.issubdtype(ntype, np.floating): 

3164 fmt = "%." + str(precision) + "f" 

3165 length = max( 

3166 len(colname), 

3167 np.max(list(map(len, list(map(lambda x: fmt % x, column))))) 

3168 ) 

3169 return 1, length+padding, fmt # right justify 

3170 

3171 return (0, 

3172 max(len(colname), 

3173 np.max(list(map(len, list(map(str, column))))))+padding, 

3174 "%s") 

3175 

3176 if header is None: 

3177 header = r.dtype.names 

3178 

3179 justify_pad_prec = [get_justify(header[i], r.__getitem__(colname), 

3180 precision[i]) 

3181 for i, colname in enumerate(r.dtype.names)] 

3182 

3183 justify_pad_prec_spacer = [] 

3184 for i in range(len(justify_pad_prec)): 

3185 just, pad, prec = justify_pad_prec[i] 

3186 if i == 0: 

3187 justify_pad_prec_spacer.append((just, pad, prec, 0)) 

3188 else: 

3189 pjust, ppad, pprec = justify_pad_prec[i-1] 

3190 if pjust == 0 and just == 1: 

3191 justify_pad_prec_spacer.append((just, pad-padding, prec, 0)) 

3192 elif pjust == 1 and just == 0: 

3193 justify_pad_prec_spacer.append((just, pad, prec, padding)) 

3194 else: 

3195 justify_pad_prec_spacer.append((just, pad, prec, 0)) 

3196 

3197 def format(item, just_pad_prec_spacer): 

3198 just, pad, prec, spacer = just_pad_prec_spacer 

3199 if just == 0: 

3200 return spacer*' ' + str(item).ljust(pad) 

3201 else: 

3202 if get_type(item) == float: 

3203 item = (prec % float(item)) 

3204 elif get_type(item) == int: 

3205 item = (prec % int(item)) 

3206 

3207 return item.rjust(pad) 

3208 

3209 textl = [] 

3210 textl.append(''.join([format(colitem, justify_pad_prec_spacer[j]) 

3211 for j, colitem in enumerate(header)])) 

3212 for i, row in enumerate(r): 

3213 textl.append(''.join([format(colitem, justify_pad_prec_spacer[j]) 

3214 for j, colitem in enumerate(row)])) 

3215 if i == 0: 

3216 textl[0] = textl[0].rstrip() 

3217 

3218 text = os.linesep.join(textl) 

3219 return text

3222@cbook.deprecated("2.2", alternative='numpy.recarray.tofile') 

3223def rec2csv(r, fname, delimiter=',', formatd=None, missing='', 

3224 missingd=None, withheader=True): 

3225 """ 

3226 Save the data from numpy recarray *r* into a 

3227 comma-/space-/tab-delimited file. The record array dtype names 

3228 will be used for column headers. 

3229 

3230 *fname*: can be a filename or a file handle. Support for gzipped 

3231 files is automatic, if the filename ends in '.gz' 

3232 

3233 *withheader*: if withheader is False, do not write the attribute 

3234 names in the first row 

3235 

3236 for formatd type FormatFloat, we override the precision to store 

3237 full precision floats in the CSV file 

3238 

3239 See Also 

3240 -------- 

3241 :func:`csv2rec` 

3242 For information about *missing* and *missingd*, which can be used to 

3243 fill in masked values into your CSV file. 

3244 """ 

3245 

3246 delimiter = str(delimiter) 

3247 

3248 if missingd is None: 

3249 missingd = dict() 

3250 

3251 def with_mask(func): 

3252 def newfunc(val, mask, mval): 

3253 if mask: 

3254 return mval 

3255 else: 

3256 return func(val) 

3257 return newfunc 

3258 

3259 if r.ndim != 1: 

3260 raise ValueError('rec2csv only operates on 1 dimensional recarrays') 

3261 

3262 formatd = get_formatd(r, formatd) 

3263 funcs = [] 

3264 for i, name in enumerate(r.dtype.names): 

3265 funcs.append(with_mask(csvformat_factory(formatd[name]).tostr)) 

3266 

3267 fh, opened = cbook.to_filehandle(fname, 'wb', return_opened=True) 

3268 writer = csv.writer(fh, delimiter=delimiter) 

3269 header = r.dtype.names 

3270 if withheader: 

3271 writer.writerow(header) 

3272 

3273 # Our list of specials for missing values 

3274 mvals = [] 

3275 for name in header: 

3276 mvals.append(missingd.get(name, missing)) 

3277 

3278 ismasked = False 

3279 if len(r): 

3280 row = r[0] 

3281 ismasked = hasattr(row, '_fieldmask') 

3282 

3283 for row in r: 

3284 if ismasked: 

3285 row, rowmask = row.item(), row._fieldmask.item() 

3286 else: 

3287 rowmask = [False] * len(row) 

3288 writer.writerow([func(val, mask, mval) for func, val, mask, mval 

3289 in zip(funcs, row, rowmask, mvals)]) 

3290 if opened: 

3291 fh.close() 

3292 

3293 

3294@cbook.deprecated('2.2', alternative='scipy.interpolate.griddata') 

3295def griddata(x, y, z, xi, yi, interp='nn'): 

3296 """ 

3297 Interpolates from a nonuniformly spaced grid to some other grid. 

3298 

3299 Fits a surface of the form z = f(`x`, `y`) to the data in the 

3300 (usually) nonuniformly spaced vectors (`x`, `y`, `z`), then 

3301 interpolates this surface at the points specified by 

3302 (`xi`, `yi`) to produce `zi`. 

3303 

3304 Parameters 

3305 ---------- 

3306 x, y, z : 1d array_like 

3307 Coordinates of grid points to interpolate from. 

3308 xi, yi : 1d or 2d array_like 

3309 Coordinates of grid points to interpolate to. 

3310 interp : string key from {'nn', 'linear'} 

3311 Interpolation algorithm, either 'nn' for natural neighbor, or 

3312 'linear' for linear interpolation. 

3313 

3314 Returns 

3315 ------- 

3316 2d float array 

3317 Array of values interpolated at (`xi`, `yi`) points. Array 

3318 will be masked is any of (`xi`, `yi`) are outside the convex 

3319 hull of (`x`, `y`). 

3320 

3321 Notes 

3322 ----- 

3323 If `interp` is 'nn' (the default), uses natural neighbor 

3324 interpolation based on Delaunay triangulation. This option is 

3325 only available if the mpl_toolkits.natgrid module is installed. 

3326 This can be downloaded from https://github.com/matplotlib/natgrid. 

3327 The (`xi`, `yi`) grid must be regular and monotonically increasing 

3328 in this case. 

3329 

3330 If `interp` is 'linear', linear interpolation is used via 

3331 matplotlib.tri.LinearTriInterpolator. 

3332 

3333 Instead of using `griddata`, more flexible functionality and other 

3334 interpolation options are available using a 

3335 matplotlib.tri.Triangulation and a matplotlib.tri.TriInterpolator. 

3336 """ 

3337 # Check input arguments. 

3338 x = np.asanyarray(x, dtype=np.float64) 

3339 y = np.asanyarray(y, dtype=np.float64) 

3340 z = np.asanyarray(z, dtype=np.float64) 

3341 if x.shape != y.shape or x.shape != z.shape or x.ndim != 1: 

3342 raise ValueError("x, y and z must be equal-length 1-D arrays") 

3343 

3344 xi = np.asanyarray(xi, dtype=np.float64) 

3345 yi = np.asanyarray(yi, dtype=np.float64) 

3346 if xi.ndim != yi.ndim: 

3347 raise ValueError("xi and yi must be arrays with the same number of " 

3348 "dimensions (1 or 2)") 

3349 if xi.ndim == 2 and xi.shape != yi.shape: 

3350 raise ValueError("if xi and yi are 2D arrays, they must have the same " 

3351 "shape") 

3352 if xi.ndim == 1: 

3353 xi, yi = np.meshgrid(xi, yi) 

3354 

3355 if interp == 'nn': 

3356 use_nn_interpolation = True 

3357 elif interp == 'linear': 

3358 use_nn_interpolation = False 

3359 else: 

3360 raise ValueError("interp keyword must be one of 'linear' (for linear " 

3361 "interpolation) or 'nn' (for natural neighbor " 

3362 "interpolation). Default is 'nn'.") 

3363 

3364 # Remove masked points. 

3365 mask = np.ma.getmask(z) 

3366 if mask is not np.ma.nomask: 

3367 x = x.compress(~mask) 

3368 y = y.compress(~mask) 

3369 z = z.compressed() 

3370 

3371 if use_nn_interpolation: 

3372 try: 

3373 from mpl_toolkits.natgrid import _natgrid 

3374 except ImportError: 

3375 raise RuntimeError( 

3376 "To use interp='nn' (Natural Neighbor interpolation) in " 

3377 "griddata, natgrid must be installed. Either install it " 

3378 "from http://github.com/matplotlib/natgrid or use " 

3379 "interp='linear' instead.") 

3380 

3381 if xi.ndim == 2: 

3382 # natgrid expects 1D xi and yi arrays. 

3383 xi = xi[0, :] 

3384 yi = yi[:, 0] 

3385 

3386 # Override default natgrid internal parameters. 

3387 _natgrid.seti(b'ext', 0) 

3388 _natgrid.setr(b'nul', np.nan) 

3389 

3390 if np.min(np.diff(xi)) < 0 or np.min(np.diff(yi)) < 0: 

3391 raise ValueError("Output grid defined by xi,yi must be monotone " 

3392 "increasing") 

3393 

3394 # Allocate array for output (buffer will be overwritten by natgridd) 

3395 zi = np.empty((yi.shape[0], xi.shape[0]), np.float64) 

3396 

3397 # Natgrid requires each array to be contiguous rather than e.g. a view 

3398 # that is a non-contiguous slice of another array. Use numpy.require 

3399 # to deal with this, which will copy if necessary. 

3400 x = np.require(x, requirements=['C']) 

3401 y = np.require(y, requirements=['C']) 

3402 z = np.require(z, requirements=['C']) 

3403 xi = np.require(xi, requirements=['C']) 

3404 yi = np.require(yi, requirements=['C']) 

3405 _natgrid.natgridd(x, y, z, xi, yi, zi) 

3406 

3407 # Mask points on grid outside convex hull of input data. 

3408 if np.any(np.isnan(zi)): 

3409 zi = np.ma.masked_where(np.isnan(zi), zi) 

3410 return zi 

3411 else: 

3412 # Linear interpolation performed using a matplotlib.tri.Triangulation 

3413 # and a matplotlib.tri.LinearTriInterpolator. 

3414 from .tri import Triangulation, LinearTriInterpolator 

3415 triang = Triangulation(x, y) 

3416 interpolator = LinearTriInterpolator(triang, z) 

3417 return interpolator(xi, yi) 

3418 

3419 

3420################################################## 

3421# Linear interpolation algorithms 

3422################################################## 

3423@cbook.deprecated("2.2", alternative="numpy.interp") 

3424def less_simple_linear_interpolation(x, y, xi, extrap=False): 

3425 """ 

3426 This function provides simple (but somewhat less so than 

3427 :func:`cbook.simple_linear_interpolation`) linear interpolation. 

3428 :func:`simple_linear_interpolation` will give a list of point 

3429 between a start and an end, while this does true linear 

3430 interpolation at an arbitrary set of points. 

3431 

3432 This is very inefficient linear interpolation meant to be used 

3433 only for a small number of points in relatively non-intensive use 

3434 cases. For real linear interpolation, use scipy. 

3435 """ 

3436 x = np.asarray(x) 

3437 y = np.asarray(y) 

3438 xi = np.atleast_1d(xi) 

3439 

3440 s = list(y.shape) 

3441 s[0] = len(xi) 

3442 yi = np.tile(np.nan, s) 

3443 

3444 for ii, xx in enumerate(xi): 

3445 bb = x == xx 

3446 if np.any(bb): 

3447 jj, = np.nonzero(bb) 

3448 yi[ii] = y[jj[0]] 

3449 elif xx < x[0]: 

3450 if extrap: 

3451 yi[ii] = y[0] 

3452 elif xx > x[-1]: 

3453 if extrap: 

3454 yi[ii] = y[-1] 

3455 else: 

3456 jj, = np.nonzero(x < xx) 

3457 jj = max(jj) 

3458 

3459 yi[ii] = y[jj] + (xx-x[jj])/(x[jj+1]-x[jj]) * (y[jj+1]-y[jj]) 

3460 

3461 return yi 

3462 

3463 

3464@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3465def slopes(x, y): 

3466 """ 

3467 :func:`slopes` calculates the slope *y*'(*x*) 

3468 

3469 The slope is estimated using the slope obtained from that of a 

3470 parabola through any three consecutive points. 

3471 

3472 This method should be superior to that described in the appendix 

3473 of A CONSISTENTLY WELL BEHAVED METHOD OF INTERPOLATION by Russel 

3474 W. Stineman (Creative Computing July 1980) in at least one aspect: 

3475 

3476 Circles for interpolation demand a known aspect ratio between 

3477 *x*- and *y*-values. For many functions, however, the abscissa 

3478 are given in different dimensions, so an aspect ratio is 

3479 completely arbitrary. 

3480 

3481 The parabola method gives very similar results to the circle 

3482 method for most regular cases but behaves much better in special 

3483 cases. 

3484 

3485 Norbert Nemec, Institute of Theoretical Physics, University or 

3486 Regensburg, April 2006 Norbert.Nemec at physik.uni-regensburg.de 

3487 

3488 (inspired by a original implementation by Halldor Bjornsson, 

3489 Icelandic Meteorological Office, March 2006 halldor at vedur.is) 

3490 """ 

3491 # Cast key variables as float. 

3492 x = np.asarray(x, float) 

3493 y = np.asarray(y, float) 

3494 

3495 yp = np.zeros(y.shape, float) 

3496 

3497 dx = x[1:] - x[:-1] 

3498 dy = y[1:] - y[:-1] 

3499 dydx = dy/dx 

3500 yp[1:-1] = (dydx[:-1] * dx[1:] + dydx[1:] * dx[:-1])/(dx[1:] + dx[:-1]) 

3501 yp[0] = 2.0 * dy[0]/dx[0] - yp[1] 

3502 yp[-1] = 2.0 * dy[-1]/dx[-1] - yp[-2] 

3503 return yp 

3504 

3505 

3506@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3507def stineman_interp(xi, x, y, yp=None): 

3508 """ 

3509 Given data vectors *x* and *y*, the slope vector *yp* and a new 

3510 abscissa vector *xi*, the function :func:`stineman_interp` uses 

3511 Stineman interpolation to calculate a vector *yi* corresponding to 

3512 *xi*. 

3513 

3514 Here's an example that generates a coarse sine curve, then 

3515 interpolates over a finer abscissa:: 

3516 

3517 x = linspace(0,2*pi,20); y = sin(x); yp = cos(x) 

3518 xi = linspace(0,2*pi,40); 

3519 yi = stineman_interp(xi,x,y,yp); 

3520 plot(x,y,'o',xi,yi) 

3521 

3522 The interpolation method is described in the article A 

3523 CONSISTENTLY WELL BEHAVED METHOD OF INTERPOLATION by Russell 

3524 W. Stineman. The article appeared in the July 1980 issue of 

3525 Creative Computing with a note from the editor stating that while 

3526 they were: 

3527 

3528 not an academic journal but once in a while something serious 

3529 and original comes in adding that this was 

3530 "apparently a real solution" to a well known problem. 

3531 

3532 For *yp* = *None*, the routine automatically determines the slopes 

3533 using the :func:`slopes` routine. 

3534 

3535 *x* is assumed to be sorted in increasing order. 

3536 

3537 For values ``xi[j] < x[0]`` or ``xi[j] > x[-1]``, the routine 

3538 tries an extrapolation. The relevance of the data obtained from 

3539 this, of course, is questionable... 

3540 

3541 Original implementation by Halldor Bjornsson, Icelandic 

3542 Meteorolocial Office, March 2006 halldor at vedur.is 

3543 

3544 Completely reworked and optimized for Python by Norbert Nemec, 

3545 Institute of Theoretical Physics, University or Regensburg, April 

3546 2006 Norbert.Nemec at physik.uni-regensburg.de 

3547 """ 

3548 

3549 # Cast key variables as float. 

3550 x = np.asarray(x, float) 

3551 y = np.asarray(y, float) 

3552 if x.shape != y.shape: 

3553 raise ValueError("'x' and 'y' must be of same shape") 

3554 

3555 if yp is None: 

3556 yp = slopes(x, y) 

3557 else: 

3558 yp = np.asarray(yp, float) 

3559 

3560 xi = np.asarray(xi, float) 

3561 yi = np.zeros(xi.shape, float) 

3562 

3563 # calculate linear slopes 

3564 dx = x[1:] - x[:-1] 

3565 dy = y[1:] - y[:-1] 

3566 s = dy/dx # note length of s is N-1 so last element is #N-2 

3567 

3568 # find the segment each xi is in 

3569 # this line actually is the key to the efficiency of this implementation 

3570 idx = np.searchsorted(x[1:-1], xi) 

3571 

3572 # now we have generally: x[idx[j]] <= xi[j] <= x[idx[j]+1] 

3573 # except at the boundaries, where it may be that xi[j] < x[0] or 

3574 # xi[j] > x[-1] 

3575 

3576 # the y-values that would come out from a linear interpolation: 

3577 sidx = s.take(idx) 

3578 xidx = x.take(idx) 

3579 yidx = y.take(idx) 

3580 xidxp1 = x.take(idx+1) 

3581 yo = yidx + sidx * (xi - xidx) 

3582 

3583 # the difference that comes when using the slopes given in yp 

3584 # using the yp slope of the left point 

3585 dy1 = (yp.take(idx) - sidx) * (xi - xidx) 

3586 # using the yp slope of the right point 

3587 dy2 = (yp.take(idx+1)-sidx) * (xi - xidxp1) 

3588 

3589 dy1dy2 = dy1*dy2 

3590 # The following is optimized for Python. The solution actually 

3591 # does more calculations than necessary but exploiting the power 

3592 # of numpy, this is far more efficient than coding a loop by hand 

3593 # in Python 

3594 yi = yo + dy1dy2 * np.choose(np.array(np.sign(dy1dy2), np.int32)+1, 

3595 ((2*xi-xidx-xidxp1)/((dy1-dy2)*(xidxp1-xidx)), 

3596 0.0, 

3597 1/(dy1+dy2),)) 

3598 return yi 

3599 

3600 

3601class GaussianKDE(object): 

3602 """ 

3603 Representation of a kernel-density estimate using Gaussian kernels. 

3604 

3605 Parameters 

3606 ---------- 

3607 dataset : array_like 

3608 Datapoints to estimate from. In case of univariate data this is a 1-D 

3609 array, otherwise a 2-D array with shape (# of dims, # of data). 

3610 

3611 bw_method : str, scalar or callable, optional 

3612 The method used to calculate the estimator bandwidth. This can be 

3613 'scott', 'silverman', a scalar constant or a callable. If a 

3614 scalar, this will be used directly as `kde.factor`. If a 

3615 callable, it should take a `GaussianKDE` instance as only 

3616 parameter and return a scalar. If None (default), 'scott' is used. 

3617 

3618 Attributes 

3619 ---------- 

3620 dataset : ndarray 

3621 The dataset with which `gaussian_kde` was initialized. 

3622 

3623 dim : int 

3624 Number of dimensions. 

3625 

3626 num_dp : int 

3627 Number of datapoints. 

3628 

3629 factor : float 

3630 The bandwidth factor, obtained from `kde.covariance_factor`, with which 

3631 the covariance matrix is multiplied. 

3632 

3633 covariance : ndarray 

3634 The covariance matrix of `dataset`, scaled by the calculated bandwidth 

3635 (`kde.factor`). 

3636 

3637 inv_cov : ndarray 

3638 The inverse of `covariance`. 

3639 

3640 Methods 

3641 ------- 

3642 kde.evaluate(points) : ndarray 

3643 Evaluate the estimated pdf on a provided set of points. 

3644 

3645 kde(points) : ndarray 

3646 Same as kde.evaluate(points) 

3647 

3648 """ 

3649 

3650 # This implementation with minor modification was too good to pass up. 

3651 # from scipy: https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/master/scipy/stats/kde.py 

3652 

3653 def __init__(self, dataset, bw_method=None): 

3654 self.dataset = np.atleast_2d(dataset) 

3655 if not np.array(self.dataset).size > 1: 

3656 raise ValueError("`dataset` input should have multiple elements.") 

3657 

3658 self.dim, self.num_dp = np.array(self.dataset).shape 

3659 isString = isinstance(bw_method, str) 

3660 

3661 if bw_method is None: 

3662 pass 

3663 elif (isString and bw_method == 'scott'): 

3664 self.covariance_factor = self.scotts_factor 

3665 elif (isString and bw_method == 'silverman'): 

3666 self.covariance_factor = self.silverman_factor 

3667 elif (np.isscalar(bw_method) and not isString): 

3668 self._bw_method = 'use constant' 

3669 self.covariance_factor = lambda: bw_method 

3670 elif callable(bw_method): 

3671 self._bw_method = bw_method 

3672 self.covariance_factor = lambda: self._bw_method(self) 

3673 else: 

3674 raise ValueError("`bw_method` should be 'scott', 'silverman', a " 

3675 "scalar or a callable") 

3676 

3677 # Computes the covariance matrix for each Gaussian kernel using 

3678 # covariance_factor(). 

3679 

3680 self.factor = self.covariance_factor() 

3681 # Cache covariance and inverse covariance of the data 

3682 if not hasattr(self, '_data_inv_cov'): 

3683 self.data_covariance = np.atleast_2d( 

3684 np.cov( 

3685 self.dataset, 

3686 rowvar=1, 

3687 bias=False)) 

3688 self.data_inv_cov = np.linalg.inv(self.data_covariance) 

3689 

3690 self.covariance = self.data_covariance * self.factor ** 2 

3691 self.inv_cov = self.data_inv_cov / self.factor ** 2 

3692 self.norm_factor = np.sqrt( 

3693 np.linalg.det( 

3694 2 * np.pi * self.covariance)) * self.num_dp 

3695 

3696 def scotts_factor(self): 

3697 return np.power(self.num_dp, -1. / (self.dim + 4)) 

3698 

3699 def silverman_factor(self): 

3700 return np.power( 

3701 self.num_dp * (self.dim + 2.0) / 4.0, -1. / (self.dim + 4)) 

3702 

3703 # Default method to calculate bandwidth, can be overwritten by subclass 

3704 covariance_factor = scotts_factor 

3705 

3706 def evaluate(self, points): 

3707 """Evaluate the estimated pdf on a set of points. 

3708 

3709 Parameters 

3710 ---------- 

3711 points : (# of dimensions, # of points)-array 

3712 Alternatively, a (# of dimensions,) vector can be passed in and 

3713 treated as a single point. 

3714 

3715 Returns 

3716 ------- 

3717 values : (# of points,)-array 

3718 The values at each point. 

3719 

3720 Raises 

3721 ------ 

3722 ValueError : if the dimensionality of the input points is different 

3723 than the dimensionality of the KDE. 

3724 

3725 """ 

3726 points = np.atleast_2d(points) 

3727 

3728 dim, num_m = np.array(points).shape 

3729 if dim != self.dim: 

3730 raise ValueError("points have dimension {}, dataset has dimension " 

3731 "{}".format(dim, self.dim)) 

3732 

3733 result = np.zeros((num_m,), dtype=float) 

3734 

3735 if num_m >= self.num_dp: 

3736 # there are more points than data, so loop over data 

3737 for i in range(self.num_dp): 

3738 diff = self.dataset[:, i, np.newaxis] - points 

3739 tdiff = np.dot(self.inv_cov, diff) 

3740 energy = np.sum(diff * tdiff, axis=0) / 2.0 

3741 result = result + np.exp(-energy) 

3742 else: 

3743 # loop over points 

3744 for i in range(num_m): 

3745 diff = self.dataset - points[:, i, np.newaxis] 

3746 tdiff = np.dot(self.inv_cov, diff) 

3747 energy = np.sum(diff * tdiff, axis=0) / 2.0 

3748 result[i] = np.sum(np.exp(-energy), axis=0) 

3749 

3750 result = result / self.norm_factor 

3751 

3752 return result 

3753 

3754 __call__ = evaluate 

3755 

3756

3760@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3761def inside_poly(points, verts): 

3762 """ 

3763 *points* is a sequence of *x*, *y* points. 

3764 *verts* is a sequence of *x*, *y* vertices of a polygon. 

3765 

3766 Return value is a sequence of indices into points for the points 

3767 that are inside the polygon. 

3768 """ 

3769 # Make a closed polygon path 

3770 poly = Path(verts) 

3771 

3772 # Check to see which points are contained within the Path 

3773 return [idx for idx, p in enumerate(points) if poly.contains_point(p)]

3776@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3777def poly_below(xmin, xs, ys): 

3778 """ 

3779 Given a sequence of *xs* and *ys*, return the vertices of a 

3780 polygon that has a horizontal base at *xmin* and an upper bound at 

3781 the *ys*. *xmin* is a scalar. 

3782 

3783 Intended for use with :meth:`matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill`, e.g.,:: 

3784 

3785 xv, yv = poly_below(0, x, y) 

3786 ax.fill(xv, yv) 

3787 """ 

3788 if any(isinstance(var, np.ma.MaskedArray) for var in [xs, ys]): 

3789 numpy = np.ma 

3790 else: 

3791 numpy = np 

3792 

3793 xs = numpy.asarray(xs) 

3794 ys = numpy.asarray(ys) 

3795 Nx = len(xs) 

3796 Ny = len(ys) 

3797 if Nx != Ny: 

3798 raise ValueError("'xs' and 'ys' must have the same length") 

3799 x = xmin*numpy.ones(2*Nx) 

3800 y = numpy.ones(2*Nx) 

3801 x[:Nx] = xs 

3802 y[:Nx] = ys 

3803 y[Nx:] = ys[::-1] 

3804 return x, y

3807@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3808def poly_between(x, ylower, yupper): 

3809 """ 

3810 Given a sequence of *x*, *ylower* and *yupper*, return the polygon 

3811 that fills the regions between them. *ylower* or *yupper* can be 

3812 scalar or iterable. If they are iterable, they must be equal in 

3813 length to *x*. 

3814 

3815 Return value is *x*, *y* arrays for use with 

3816 :meth:`matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill`. 

3817 """ 

3818 if any(isinstance(var, np.ma.MaskedArray) for var in [ylower, yupper, x]): 

3819 numpy = np.ma 

3820 else: 

3821 numpy = np 

3822 

3823 Nx = len(x) 

3824 if not cbook.iterable(ylower): 

3825 ylower = ylower*numpy.ones(Nx) 

3826 

3827 if not cbook.iterable(yupper): 

3828 yupper = yupper*numpy.ones(Nx) 

3829 

3830 x = numpy.concatenate((x, x[::-1])) 

3831 y = numpy.concatenate((yupper, ylower[::-1])) 

3832 return x, y

3834 

3835@cbook.deprecated('2.2') 

3836def is_closed_polygon(X): 

3837 """ 

3838 Tests whether first and last object in a sequence are the same. These are 

3839 presumably coordinates on a polygonal curve, in which case this function 

3840 tests if that curve is closed. 

3841 """ 

3842 return np.all(X[0] == X[-1])

3847 """ 

3848 return a list of (ind0, ind1) such that mask[ind0:ind1].all() is 

3849 True and we cover all such regions

3851 return cbook.contiguous_regions(mask)

3854@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3855def cross_from_below(x, threshold): 

3856 """ 

3857 return the indices into *x* where *x* crosses some threshold from 

3858 below, e.g., the i's where:: 

3859 

3860 x[i-1]<threshold and x[i]>=threshold 

3861 

3862 Example code:: 

3863 

3864 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

3865 

3866 t = np.arange(0.0, 2.0, 0.1) 

3867 s = np.sin(2*np.pi*t) 

3868 

3869 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

3870 ax.plot(t, s, '-o') 

3871 ax.axhline(0.5) 

3872 ax.axhline(-0.5) 

3873 

3874 ind = cross_from_below(s, 0.5) 

3875 ax.vlines(t[ind], -1, 1) 

3876 

3877 ind = cross_from_above(s, -0.5) 

3878 ax.vlines(t[ind], -1, 1) 

3879 

3880 plt.show() 

3881 

3882 See Also 

3883 -------- 

3884 :func:`cross_from_above` and :func:`contiguous_regions` 

3885 

3886 """ 

3887 x = np.asarray(x) 

3888 ind = np.nonzero((x[:-1] < threshold) & (x[1:] >= threshold))[0] 

3889 if len(ind): 

3890 return ind+1 

3891 else: 

3892 return ind 

3893 

3894 

3895@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3896def cross_from_above(x, threshold): 

3897 """ 

3898 return the indices into *x* where *x* crosses some threshold from 

3899 below, e.g., the i's where:: 

3900 

3901 x[i-1]>threshold and x[i]<=threshold 

3902 

3903 See Also 

3904 -------- 

3905 :func:`cross_from_below` and :func:`contiguous_regions` 

3906 

3907 """ 

3908 x = np.asarray(x) 

3909 ind = np.nonzero((x[:-1] >= threshold) & (x[1:] < threshold))[0] 

3910 if len(ind): 

3911 return ind+1 

3912 else: 

3913 return ind

3916################################################## 

3917# Vector and path length geometry calculations 

3918################################################## 

3919@cbook.deprecated('2.2') 

3920def vector_lengths(X, P=2., axis=None): 

3921 """ 

3922 Finds the length of a set of vectors in *n* dimensions. This is 

3923 like the :func:`numpy.norm` function for vectors, but has the ability to 

3924 work over a particular axis of the supplied array or matrix. 

3925 

3926 Computes ``(sum((x_i)^P))^(1/P)`` for each ``{x_i}`` being the 

3927 elements of *X* along the given axis. If *axis* is *None*, 

3928 compute over all elements of *X*. 

3929 """ 

3930 X = np.asarray(X) 

3931 return (np.sum(X**(P), axis=axis))**(1./P) 

3932 

3933 

3934@cbook.deprecated('2.2') 

3935def distances_along_curve(X): 

3936 """ 

3937 Computes the distance between a set of successive points in *N* dimensions. 

3938 

3939 Where *X* is an *M* x *N* array or matrix. The distances between 

3940 successive rows is computed. Distance is the standard Euclidean 

3941 distance. 

3942 """ 

3943 X = np.diff(X, axis=0) 

3944 return vector_lengths(X, axis=1) 

3945 

3946 

3947@cbook.deprecated('2.2') 

3948def path_length(X): 

3949 """ 

3950 Computes the distance travelled along a polygonal curve in *N* dimensions. 

3951 

3952 Where *X* is an *M* x *N* array or matrix. Returns an array of 

3953 length *M* consisting of the distance along the curve at each point 

3954 (i.e., the rows of *X*). 

3955 """ 

3956 X = distances_along_curve(X) 

3957 return np.concatenate((np.zeros(1), np.cumsum(X))) 

3958 

3959 

3960@cbook.deprecated('2.2') 

3961def quad2cubic(q0x, q0y, q1x, q1y, q2x, q2y): 

3962 """ 

3963 Converts a quadratic Bezier curve to a cubic approximation. 

3964 

3965 The inputs are the *x* and *y* coordinates of the three control 

3966 points of a quadratic curve, and the output is a tuple of *x* and 

3967 *y* coordinates of the four control points of the cubic curve. 

3968 """ 

3969 # TODO: Candidate for deprecation -- no longer used internally 

3970 

3971 # c0x, c0y = q0x, q0y 

3972 c1x, c1y = q0x + 2./3. * (q1x - q0x), q0y + 2./3. * (q1y - q0y) 

3973 c2x, c2y = c1x + 1./3. * (q2x - q0x), c1y + 1./3. * (q2y - q0y) 

3974 # c3x, c3y = q2x, q2y 

3975 return q0x, q0y, c1x, c1y, c2x, c2y, q2x, q2y

3978@cbook.deprecated("2.2") 

3979def offset_line(y, yerr): 

3980 """ 

3981 Offsets an array *y* by +/- an error and returns a tuple 

3982 (y - err, y + err). 

3983 

3984 The error term can be: 

3985 

3986 * A scalar. In this case, the returned tuple is obvious. 

3987 * A vector of the same length as *y*. The quantities y +/- err are computed 

3988 component-wise. 

3989 * A tuple of length 2. In this case, yerr[0] is the error below *y* and 

3990 yerr[1] is error above *y*. For example:: 

3991 

3992 import numpy as np 

3993 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

3994 

3995 x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, num=100, endpoint=True) 

3996 y = np.sin(x) 

3997 y_minus, y_plus = mlab.offset_line(y, 0.1) 

3998 plt.plot(x, y) 

3999 plt.fill_between(x, y_minus, y2=y_plus) 

4000 plt.show() 

4001 

4002 """ 

4003 if cbook.is_numlike(yerr) or (cbook.iterable(yerr) and 

4004 len(yerr) == len(y)): 

4005 ymin = y - yerr 

4006 ymax = y + yerr 

4007 elif len(yerr) == 2: 

4008 ymin, ymax = y - yerr[0], y + yerr[1] 

4009 else: 

4010 raise ValueError("yerr must be scalar, 1xN or 2xN") 

4011 return ymin, ymax
